AIGLE.plugins package¶

Submodules¶

AIGLE.plugins.openmm_integrator module¶

class AIGLE.plugins.openmm_integrator.GLEIntegrator(config, timestep)[source]¶

Bases: CustomIntegrator

The integrator for generalized langevin equations (GLE): ma = F + int K(t-s) v(s) ds + n(t) For each particle, assume the memory and noise effects are isotropic.

addMemoryComponents(mem_cf_cos, mem_cf_sin)[source]¶

Adds memory components to the integrator. FvCos[i] and Fvsin[i] value only, in the unit of length (nm). MemCoefCos[i] and MemCoefSin[i] value only, in the the unit of (1/ps)^2. Args:

mem_cf_cos (np.array): shape=(nparticle,3, nmodes), (value only) in unit of nm (1/ps)^2 mem_cf_sin (np.array): shape=(nparticle,3, nmodes), (value only) in unit of (1/ps)^2

addNoiseComponents(noise_cf_cos, noise_cf_sin)[source]¶

Adds noise components to the integrator. NoiseCos[i] and NoiseSin[i] have the unit of length (nm). NoiseCoefCos[i] and NoiseCoefSin[i] have the unit of (1/ps)^2. Args:

noise_cf_cos (np.array): shape=(nparticle,3, nmodes), (value only) in unit of (1/ps)^2 noise_cf_sin (np.array): shape=(nparticle,3, nmodes), (value only) in unit of (1/ps)^2

get_langevin_integrator(temperature, timestep, epsilon=0.001)[source]¶
Args:

temperature (float): in unit of Kelvin timestep (float): in unit of picosecond epsilon (float): the minimum value of the friction coefficient, in unit of 1/picosecond.

epsilon should be positive to avoid negative friction coefficient derived from GLE.

Returns:

a Langevin Equation integrator with the instantaneous friction derived from the GLE integrator

setIntegrationScheme()[source]¶

leap frog

updateMemory()[source]¶

Update each memory component. Then sum up the memory force.

updateNoise()[source]¶

Update each noise component. Then sum up the noise.

class AIGLE.plugins.openmm_integrator.LEIntegrator(temperature, timestep, friction)[source]¶

Bases: CustomIntegrator

The integrator for langevin equations (LE): ma = F - friction*v + white_noise For each particle, assume the memory and noise effects are isotropic.
